title: Plane takes off in a gigantic storm with lightning illuminating the night sky
text:

A passenger has captured the moment his plane flew through a raging storm as bolts of lightning light up the night sky.
While aviation experts and airlines are keen to point out that aircraft are built to withstand lightning strikes, this video will still be terrifying for many.
James Reeves was flying with United Airlines from Chicago to Houston in the U.S, and was lucky enough to get the window seat to film the action unfolding outside.
Scroll down for more video
Passenger films remarkable thunder and lightning from plane The sky above Chicago in the U.S. is lit up by many bolts of lightning as a storm rage on
James Reeves recorded the stunning display of extreme weather from his window seat
As the plane ascends and the United staff run through the take-off instructions, the dark and cloudy skyline is lit up by several bursts of lightning.
However the flight attendant continue to address the passengers in a calm manner, and there are no shrieks or screams from those on board.

British tourist suffers horrific leg injury after 'false... 55 shares Speaking to MailOnline Travel after watching the video, Dai Whittingham, chief executive of the UK Flight Safety Committee said: 'Some of the flashes you see closer to the aircraft are actually reflections from the anti-collision high-intensity white strobe lights, but the thunder cell itself would be five to ten miles away.
'Pilots will always try to avoid passing through thunder cells – they do show up on the weather radar, but you sometimes have to aim at the area showing the weakest activity.
As the storm continue, the cabin crew continue on in calm fashion with their safety announcements
Aircraft are built to cope with a lightning strike, but pilots will often wait for a storm to pass before taking off
'The dangers arising from thunderstorms fall into three areas: wind and turbulence; lightning strikes and hail stones.
'Hail is obvious and, depending on the size of the stones, can cause significant damage to the aircraft – clearly, you would be hitting the stones at normal flying speeds which will range from 200-300 mph or more.
'Lightning strikes can cause damage to aircraft structures and components, typically leaving small holes as the strike vents outwards.
Electrical activity generated by a storm can sometimes affect the radio transmission from aircraft
'Pilots will always avoid flying into a thunderstorm if they can. Where storms are situated over an airport, they will either wait for it to move or land somewhere else.
'A storm nearby also affects aircraft refuelling and the electrical activity can affect radio transmissions as well.'
Last month MailOnline reported dramatic point-of-view footage from inside a passenger jet captured during a violent landing in severe weather in Amsterdam.
The video was captured on July 25 and shows the inside of the plane bumping around in a violent manner while coming into land at Amsterdam Airport Schiphol.
Dramatic emergency landing inside plane during bad weather People can be heard voicing their panic and anticipating the touch-down as the video maker stares down and holds his camera towards the ground – it is unclear whether he has adopted the brace position.
The plane then lands with a thud and the relieved passengers respond by clapping and celebrating as the aircraft manoeuvres safely along the tarmac before coming to a stop.
And days later one of American Airlines’ new Boeing 787 Dreamliners was badly battered by hail on a flight from Beijing to Dallas Monday and had to turn back.
The Texas-bound Flight 88 carrying 209 passengers and a crew of 13 on board returned to Beijing after sustaining hail damage 44 minutes into the voyage, said airline spokeswoman Andrea Huguely.
The pilots landed the banged up aircraft safely, and no injuries were reported.
